item.description:
The team behind the study used a compound known as P7C3-A20 to restore normal levels of NAD+, a molecule essential for brain cell energy and survival. The results, described as ‚Äústriking‚Äù by the authors, open a new direction for Alzheimer‚Äôs research and raise cautious hopes about potential human applications.

Alzheimer‚Äôs disease has long been considered a one-way path of decline, with treatments mainly aimed at slowing progression or delaying symptoms. Despite more than a century of study, no therapeutic strategy had ever succeeded in reversing the brain damage or memory loss associated with the condition. But researchers from University Hospitals Cleveland Medical Center, along with Case Western Reserve University and the Louis Stokes Cleveland VA Medical Center, decided to test a radical question: what if the brain could bounce back?

Their results, published in Cell Reports Medicine on December 22, 2025, reveal a possible turning point. By focusing on brain metabolism, specifically the ability of cells to maintain adequate levels of NAD+, they found that even severely damaged brains in mouse models could heal, both structurally and functionally. According to the lead author, Dr. Kalyani Chaubey, the approach differs from other NAD+-boosting strategies, offering a controlled method that avoids dangerous side effects.

Damaged Brain Tissue Restored After Late-Stage Intervention

The research involved two well-established mouse models of Alzheimer‚Äôs: one mimicking amyloid buildup and the other simulating tau-related degeneration. Both models showed hallmark signs of the disease, including memory loss, blood-brain barrier breakdown, oxidative stress, and neuronal dysfunction. Importantly, these mice also showed a sharp drop in NAD+ levels, mirroring what was found in human Alzheimer‚Äôs brain tissue.

When scientists used P7C3-A20 to restore NAD+ balance, the results were more powerful than expected. Mice that had already reached an advanced stage of disease not only stopped declining but regained full cognitive function. According to the study, this recovery included improved memory, normalized behavior, and even the repair of cellular structures that had been heavily damaged.

As noted in the publication, P7C3-A20 restored long-term potentiation in the hippocampus, reversed tau phosphorylation, and repaired the blood-brain barrier, all of which are considered major pathological features of Alzheimer‚Äôs. In blood tests, levels of phosphorylated tau 217, a clinical biomarker used in human diagnosis, also returned to normal.

Alzheimer‚Äôs Damage Tied to Metabolic Imbalance, Not Just Cell Death

A key insight of the study is that cognitive decline in Alzheimer‚Äôs may not always be due to irreversible neuron loss, but rather to cells losing their ability to function due to energy imbalance. According to Dr. Andrew A. Pieper, senior author and Director of the Brain Health Medicines Center at UH, ‚ÄúRestoring the brain‚Äôs energy balance achieved pathological and functional recovery in both lines of mice with advanced Alzheimer‚Äôs.‚Äù

This challenges the widely held assumption that once neurons are lost, the damage is final. In fact, the study found that some brain regions showed no significant neuron death, yet still presented major symptoms, which reversed once NAD+ levels were restored.

According to the researchers, P7C3-A20 works differently from over-the-counter supplements aimed at boosting NAD+. Unlike unregulated products that may flood the body with excess NAD+, which in animal studies has been linked to cancer, P7C3-A20 supports normal NAD+ homeostasis during stress without pushing levels too high. Dr. Pieper warned that self-medicating with NAD+ supplements is not the same as the controlled pharmacological approach used in this research.

Moving From Prevention to Potential Recovery

The implications of these findings could be wide-reaching. Unlike previous trials focused on prevention or slowing decline, this research suggests that recovery from Alzheimer‚Äôs symptoms may be possible, at least in certain cases. According to the data, P7C3-A20 not only prevented the disease when given early but also reversed it when introduced during advanced stages, as demonstrated in both amyloid- and tau-driven mouse models.

The approach now needs to be tested in human clinical trials, which the team is actively preparing. The compound is being commercialized by Glengary Brain Health, co-founded by Dr. Pieper in Cleveland, to facilitate this transition.

Researchers remain cautious, acknowledging that mouse models do not fully replicate human Alzheimer‚Äôs, a ‚Äúcomplex, multifactorial, uniquely human disease,‚Äù as Dr. Pieper told Fox News Digital. Yet, the robust and repeatable effects observed in the study have opened a promising new path. While the team continues its work, attention is now turning to other age-related neurodegenerative diseases that might benefit from the same strategy of restoring brain energy balance.¬†

item.description:
• Different cooking methods, like roasting or steaming, enhance flavor and lock in nutrients.
  • Cooking them with healthy fats enhances the absorption of certain vitamins.
  • Proper selection and storage help preserve the potatoes‚Äô freshness and nutritional value.

If you‚Äôre a fan of sweet potatoes, you‚Äôre certainly not alone. Demand for the root vegetable has remained high over the past decade, thanks in part to its promotion to ‚Äúsuperfood‚Äù status and to the increasingly popular sweet potato fries.¬†

Getting the most out of your sweet potatoes has everything to do with how you prepare them.¬†There are a variety of ways to cook this beloved veggie, and each of them has unique benefits for enhancing the taste and nutrient density. From roasting to steaming, dietitians dish on how you can maximize both the flavor and nutrition for your next spud-focused dinner.¬†

Sweet Potato Nutrition Profile

The U.S. grows a variety of sweet potato types, each with its own unique color, taste and texture. Among the most popular is the orange-fleshed variety, commonly seen stacked high in the produce section of your local market. They are packed with nutrients that contribute to a healthy diet, including potassium, which is important for heart health, and plenty of fiber to support digestion. One small sweet potato provides:

  • Calories: 112¬†
  • Carbohydrates: 26g¬†
  • Dietary Fiber: 4g¬†
  • Total Sugar: 5.5g¬†
  • Added Sugar: 0g
  • Protein: 2g¬†
  • Total Fat: 0g¬†
  • Saturated Fat: 0g¬†
  • Cholesterol: 0mg
  • Sodium: 70mg

How to Cook Sweet Potatoes, According To Dietitians

Roasted Sweet Potatoes

One of the best ways to cook sweet potatoes to maximize both flavor and nutrition is roasting. ‚ÄúRoasting sweet potatoes with a small amount of oil allows the natural sugars to caramelize, creating a sweeter, more complex and slightly nutty flavor,‚Äù explains Marra Burroughs, D.C.N., RD, ‚ÄúDry-heat methods like roasting also help preserve beta-carotene, a powerful antioxidant and precursor to vitamin A. Beta-carotene is fat-soluble, so pairing sweet potatoes with a bit of healthy fat, such as olive oil, can also further enhance its absorption by the body,‚Äù Burroughs adds.

Burroughs says she leaves the skins on for added fiber and cuts the sweet potatoes into even-size pieces to help them cook more uniformly. Then, she tosses them in olive oil, and roasts them on a baking sheet at 450¬∞F until they‚Äôre soft on the inside but crispy on the outside, 20 to 30 minutes.¬†

Steamed Sweet Potatoes

Avery Zenker, M.A.N., RD, says she enjoys the caramelized flavor that roasting gives sweet potatoes, but recommends steaming them first to preserve even more nutrients. ‚ÄúThe combination of steaming first to soften the potatoes, then roasting in the oven to develop flavor, helps reduce the amount of time sweet potatoes are exposed to the high and dry heat in the oven, and helps retain the nutrients. This allows the sweet potatoes to caramelize, but not become too brown, to balance maximum flavor with high nutrient content.‚Äù

You can try this at home by steaming halved sweet potatoes for about 15 to 20 minutes, then carefully coating them in olive oil and placing them cut-side down on a baking sheet before roasting them for another 10 to 15 minutes. Serve them with your favorite toppings, like a dollop of tangy Greek-style yogurt and fresh chives.

Air-Fried Sweet Potatoes

Because air fryers typically require less cooking time, cardiology dietitian Michelle Routhenstein recommends this method for preserving more cardioprotective nutrients like beta-carotene, vitamin C and potassium. Routhenstein notes that ‚Äúadding a little healthy fat, such as avocado oil, helps your body absorb the fat-soluble [nutrient] beta-carotene, the antioxidant that gives sweet potatoes their orange color. Beta-carotene also helps reduce oxidative stress and inflammation, both of which are linked to heart disease.‚Äù

In addition to coating them in a healthy fat, Routhenstein enjoys sprinkling them with ground cinnamon to enhance their natural sweetness. When cut into wedges and air-fried at¬† 400¬∞F, they should take only 15 to 20 minutes to become crisp and delicious.

Boiled Sweet Potatoes

While boiling vegetables does cause some nutrients to leach into the water, Jordan Langhough, RD, says that moist cooking methods create less oxidation, which, in turn, preserves more antioxidants. Langhough shares that boiling sweet potatoes can result in a lower glycemic impact compared to baking: ‚ÄúThe moisture from boiling [makes] the starches slower to digest, which means a more steady release of energy, which will [cause] blood sugar [to rise] more slowly.‚Äù

Place whole sweet potatoes in a pot of water and cook them for about 20 to 40 minutes, depending on size, or roughly 10 to 20 minutes when cubed or when added to soups.

Tips for Selecting and Storing Sweet Potatoes

To get the most nutrients out of sweet potatoes, it‚Äôs important to know how to select them as well as how to store them. Here are some tips that can help you do just that.

  • Look for smooth, slightly shiny skin, and avoid those with blemishes and wrinkles.
  • Feel for a dense, firm sweet potato with no soft spots. Fresh sweet potatoes are heavy due to their high water and nutritional content, becoming lighter and softer as they begin to decay.
  • Uncooked sweet potatoes should be stored in a cool, dark place with good air circulation. A paper bag inside a kitchen drawer is ideal. Avoid washing them before use, and do not place them in the refrigerator or next to other fruits and vegetables, as they emit gases that can cause premature decay.
  • Cooked sweet potatoes should be cooled completely before storing. Place them in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to five days or in the freezer for up to a year. Leftover sweet potatoes that are chilled or reheated can actually contain more resistant starch, which is digested more slowly than ordinary starch. Its slowed digestion leads to potential health benefits like improved insulin sensitivity and enhanced gut health.

Our Expert Take

Sweet potatoes are rich in beta-carotene, vitamin C and potassium, which are essential nutrients for a healthy diet. To preserve these valuable nutrients and maximize the flavor, dietitians recommend cooking methods such as roasting, steaming, air-frying and boiling. They also recommend incorporating oils to help the body absorb the fat-soluble nutrients like beta-carotene. Choosing fresh sweet potatoes at the supermarket and storing leftovers properly is key to enjoying the best nutritional content.

item.description:
Imagine waking up already feeling drained, as if you never slept at all. Or noticing that your hands feel inexplicably stiff and swollen, making simple tasks like opening a jar or even typing feel unusually difficult.

It‚Äôs easy to chalk such symptoms up to stress, getting older or an especially demanding week, but for nearly one in 10 Americans, these and other subtle, often-dismissed changes are signs of something more complex.

In fact, many of the tens of millions of people living with autoimmune diseases have lived with some form of the condition months or years before receiving a clear diagnosis. That‚Äôs because symptoms often come and go, overlap with other conditions or are simply too nonspecific to raise immediate concern.

As a result, autoimmune diseases can quietly hide in plain sight. When they do emerge, ‚Äúdepending on the extent of the disease, it can affect a person‚Äôs ability to do everyday activities such as working, eating certain foods or even caring for themself,‚Äù says Dr. Stephanie Sasha De La Guarda, a family medicine physician at Baptist Health South Florida.

Understanding what autoimmune diseases are, what triggers them and how they‚Äôre treated can be a powerful first step toward clarity, proper care and lasting relief.

James Van Der Beek, Celine Dion, more stars open up about their health struggles

1 of 66

Celebrities such as Selma Blair, Jada Pinkett Smith, Selena Gomez and Justin Bieber have embraced speaking out about ongoing health issues, encouraging fans to do the same. Here are more stars who opened up about their health struggles.

The "Dawson's Creek" star James Van Der Beek revealed in November 2024 that he is battling Stage 3 colorectal cancer.

A year later, the 48-year-old actor announced an auction of memorabilia from his teen heartthrob heyday through a partnership with Propstore scheduled for Dec. 5‚Äì7, 2025.

What is an autoimmune disease? Can autoimmune disease kill you?

To have an autoimmune disease "means that the immune system ‚Äì which normally protects the body from infections and cancer ‚Äì mistakenly targets and attacks the body‚Äôs own healthy tissues,‚Äù says Dr. Alexandra Reese, a rheumatologist at Cleveland Clinic.

Instead of recognizing organs, joints or glands as ‚Äúself,‚Äù immune cells misidentify them as threats and mount a chronic inflammatory response. Over time, this persistent immune attack "can lead to tissue damage and organ dysfunction,‚Äù says Reese.

Autoimmune disease is so widespread in part because there are between 80 and 150 autoimmune diseases, each affecting different parts of the body. Some of the most common ones include rheumatoid arthritis, which targets the joints; lupus, which can affect the skin, kidneys, heart and brain; multiple sclerosis, which damages the protective covering of nerves; type 1 diabetes, which destroys insulin-producing cells in the pancreas; Hashimoto‚Äôs thyroiditis, which impairs thyroid function; and inflammatory bowel diseases such as Crohn‚Äôs disease and ulcerative colitis.

Symptoms vary depending on the condition and the organs involved, but "living with an autoimmune disease often means managing symptoms like fatigue, joint pain and organ dysfunction, which can significantly impact physical abilities, social interactions and work life,‚Äù says Reese. Muscle weakness, swelling, rashes, digestive issues and brain fog are other commonly reported associated issues that can affect one's lifestyle and livelihood.

And while some autoimmune diseases are mild or intermittent, others are progressive and potentially life-threatening, particularly when vital organs such as the kidneys, lungs, heart or nervous system are involved.

MS is more common than you think: Christina Applegate, Selma Blair and John King have it.

What causes autoimmune disease?

Autoimmune diseases arise from a complex interplay of genetics, environmental exposures and immune system dysregulation.

Genetics alone are rarely enough to cause the disease. Environmental factors ‚Äúsuch as smoking or chemical pollutants‚Äù also appear to play a significant role, says De La Guarda. She adds that viral and bacterial infections are also among the most studied triggers.

Hormonal influences are also important, says Reese, particularly because autoimmune diseases disproportionately affect women and often emerge during reproductive years or following major hormonal shifts such as pregnancy.

In many cases, it‚Äôs a combination of factors. ‚ÄúSome diseases, like rheumatoid arthritis, are thought to result from a ‚Äòtwo-hit phenomenon,'" says Reese, "where a person has a genetic predisposition and then encounters an environmental exposure."

Other contributors may include chronic stress, poor sleep and disruptions to the gut microbiome. In fact, research increasingly suggests that the gut, which houses a large portion of the immune system, plays a critical role in immune tolerance. That's likely because, when the balance of gut bacteria is disturbed, immune regulation may falter, increasing inflammation and susceptibility to autoimmune reactions.

Noted: Improving gut health can do more than help digestion

How are autoimmune diseases treated?

No matter what's behind them, autoimmune diseases generally cannot be cured. ‚ÄúBut a variety of treatment options are available to help control symptoms, with the ultimate goal of preserving and improving patients‚Äô quality of life,‚Äù says Reese.

Treatment is highly individualized and depends on the specific disease, the organs affected and symptom severity. In clinical care, physicians aim to reduce immune system overactivity, control inflammation and prevent long-term damage, which is often done through medication. ‚ÄúSome of these medicines include insulin, thyroid hormone replacement drugs, anti-inflammatory medications, corticosteroids, immunosuppressants, biologics and disease-modifying antirheumatic drugs,‚Äù says De La Guarda.

For some patients, particularly during severe disease flares, hospitalization may also be necessary to stabilize organ function, manage pain or treat complications such as infections. Long-term care often also involves regular monitoring through blood tests, imaging and specialist visits to ensure disease activity remains under control.

At home, lifestyle strategies play an important supporting role. Adequate sleep, stress management and regular low-impact physical activity can all help reduce inflammation and preserve mobility.

Many patients also benefit from physical therapy, occupational therapy or counseling to address both the physical and emotional challenges of chronic illness. And while no single diet treats autoimmune disease, balanced nutrition that supports gut health and limits ultra-processed foods is recommended to improve overall well-being.

Thanks to advances in diagnosis and treatment, "individuals with autoimmune diseases can live fulfilling lives by adhering to therapy, avoiding triggers, making healthy lifestyle changes and maintaining regular monitoring,‚Äù says Reese. Ultimately, ‚Äúliving with an autoimmune disease is not easy," she acknowledges, "but remember that you are never alone; there are millions of people around the world walking a similar path."

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: What is an autoimmune disease? What triggers them?

item.description:
People who greet the new year with hope, ambitious plans and optimised gut microbiomes might be obnoxiously apparent at the moment, but we all know they‚Äôre a minority. Most of us lurched into 2026 catastrophically depleted and grey-faced, juggling deep Lemsip dependency with a deeper overdraft and a sense of ever-deepening global geopolitical foreboding. There is, however, one thing that fills me with buoyant optimism now and always: science. I don‚Äôt understand it, but I‚Äôm delighted it‚Äôs out there, making things better.

I was booted out of my leaden year-end listlessness by The Atlantic‚Äôs list of 55 Facts That Blew Our Minds in 2025. Did you know, for example, that scientists at UC Berkeley created a new colour? (It‚Äôs called ‚Äúolo‚Äù and it‚Äôs sort of teal.) Or that doctors treated a baby with a rare genetic disorder with custom gene editing? There were more wonders in the Smithsonian‚Äôs list of last year‚Äôs fascinating scientific discoveries: ichthyosaurs, extinct marine reptiles, had ‚Äústealth flippers‚Äù, snails can regrow eyes within a month, and ‚Äúflamingos form tornado-like vortices as they probe for prey‚Äù, which is pure poetry (it looks pretty cool too, I watched one do it on YouTube). Still on an animal theme, entomologists discovered a ‚Äúbone collector‚Äù caterpillar that conceals itself in the body parts of its prey (I‚Äôm sure he‚Äôs lovely when you get to know him). 2025 was also the year science made oyster mushrooms play keyboards (sort of), astronomers discovered more than 100 moons in our solar system and medical researchers created replica womb lining and made astonishing progress towards lab-grown teeth.

Science is awe-inspiring; it‚Äôs the one thing that makes me really look forward to 2026. I know big brains are already working tirelessly on the stuff we‚Äôre desperate for them to sort out: climate collapse, plastic waste and ecosystem failure; cures for dementia and cancer and the chronic conditions, such as long Covid, that blight the lives of many of my loved ones and yours. But smaller stuff is cool too. Far be it from me to try to direct the course of human inquiry, but I have a few suggestions of projects that would sit well on a ‚Äúmind-blowing discoveries‚Äù list this time next year. I can‚Äôt manage 55, but here are nine.

Are we really sure sitting down is bad for us? It would be great if someone clever took another look at that.

It was cool when you discovered a supersized stick insect last year, guys, and I loved all the new insects generally ‚Äì four new wasps! Wow! Just a suggestion, but I think global morale would be vastly improved by the discovery of a new cute, fluffy mammal. Maybe keep a lookout while you‚Äôre wasp hunting?

Live translation software has become incredible: I recently read about a journalist going round Japan using it with astonishing success. This year it needs to tackle the real challenge: pets. You want to know if your cat loves you? I hope you‚Äôre ready for the truth.

Earworm removal. I can‚Äôt cope with another year of my husband humming The Muppets theme.

I have two alternative renewable energy sources I suggest we investigate: scrolling ‚Äì we‚Äôre all doing it, couldn‚Äôt we be hooked up to something to generate power with our fingers? Also: middle-aged female rage. Show me an unemptied bin and I could easily power the National Grid for 10 minutes.

I‚Äôm a keen follower of research that suggests how short bursts of exercise can improve your health ‚Äì the finding announced last week that 10 minutes‚Äô exercise could help protect against the progression of bowel cancer was excellent. Perhaps this year, slumping over to the fridge could be discovered to have unexpected health benefits.

Speaking of exercise, I know time is relative, but physics needs to explore what happens when you run on a treadmill. Civilisations rise and fall, geological eras pass, and the digital display still says four minutes. Make it make sense.

Wearable technology has made great strides (unlike me on a treadmill), but it needs to tackle one of humankind‚Äôs biggest problems: bedtime procrastination. I want a wearable that, come 10pm, undresses me, brushes my teeth, then airlifts me to bed in the efficient if undignified way they rehomed that rhino last March. Failing that, I would settle for one that administers an electric shock of increasing intensity every five minutes I loll on the sofa post-bedtime.

Geese: we urgently need to work out what their angry deal is. Forget the orcas; it‚Äôs geese we need to worry about.

item.description:
Insulin resistance is a complex condition in which the human body does not respond to the pancreatic hormone insulin as it should under normal conditions. According to the Cleveland Clinic, it is associated with a number of disorders, including cardiovascular disease, metabolic syndrome, PCOS, and obesity.

Also Read | Baby health 101: Doctor reveals essential and optional tests every newborn should get after birth

Taking to Instagram on January 5, online fitness coach Julie Capozziello shared a video where she noted that women often hear that they are unable to lose weight because of their insulin resistance, and then, paradoxically, are asked to lose weight to solve the problem.

She went on to share a five-step solution, laying out a detailed, easy-to-follow plan to reverse insulin resistance and lose weight.

1. Build muscle

‚ÄúSkeletal muscle is the largest site of glucose disposal in your whole body,‚Äù noted Julie.

‚ÄúBasically, what that means is that when you eat a carb, it turns into sugar in your blood. That sugar has to go somewhere. And the place of storage is your muscle.‚Äù

When we work (contract) our muscles, they pull the sugar out from the blood and store it there. Utilising more muscles results in more sugar being pulled out of the blood and the body requiring less insulin to manage the remaining blood sugar.

A well-established method to build muscles is through weight or resistance training. ‚ÄúResistance training increases something called GLUT4 (Glucose Transporter Type 4) for the muscles,‚Äù explained the fitness coach. ‚ÄúGLUT4 allows glucose to enter the muscle without causing large insulin spikes.‚Äù

Resistance training helps with insulin resistance even without weight loss. As such, many women who do only cardio stay insulin resistant, she highlighted.

2. Eat protein first

While increasing protein intake is essential, the order in which we eat our meals also has an important role to play. Starting our meals with protein leads to smaller glucose spikes as the sugar enters our bloodstream more slowly.

‚ÄúSlower digestion equals lower insulin response. And lower insulin response means better sensitivity over time,‚Äù noted Julie.

It is also a great tip for those who feel ‚Äúsnacky or exhausted after meals,‚Äù as the condition can be caused by not having enough protein or not eating meals in the right order, such as eating carbs first. This leads to getting full and not finishing the proteins.

‚ÄúA good goal is having one gram of protein per pound of goal body weight,‚Äù added Julie.

3. Walk post-meals

Julie claimed that she could not overstate the importance of postprandial walks, or short walks taken immediately after meals.

‚ÄúI repeat myself because I know that this is gonna make your life so much better,‚Äù she shared. ‚ÄúAnd it doesn't need to be a long walk. Light movement post-meals has been shown to increase glucose uptake by the muscles almost immediately. And studies show that it could reduce those glucose spikes by 20 to 30 percent.

4. Regulate sleep and stress

Sleep and stress have a major effect on overall health, and insulin resistance in particular, revealed Julie.

‚ÄúSleep deprivation alone can induce insulin resistance because short sleep increases cortisol, and cortisol blocks insulin signalling,‚Äù she explained, suggesting that getting a sleep tracker might help.

5. Data to drive behaviour

‚ÄúMy last tip is to use data to drive behaviour,‚Äù noted the fitness coach. ‚ÄúAnd what I mean by that is you can't really improve what you don't measure. You can't really build muscle if you're not keeping track of your lifts.‚Äù

When it comes to calorie intake, Julie said that most people underreport calories by 20 percent. This means that some people can eat too little instead of too much. Taking thehelp of an app and tracking what we are eating every day can give us a better idea of what actually needs to change.

Note to readers: This article is for informational purposes only and not a substitute for professional medical advice. Always seek the advice of your doctor with any questions about a medical condition.

item.description:
If there‚Äôs water anywhere near Lexi, she‚Äôs already clocked it, logged it, and decided she probably needs to be in it. Her humans at @lexi_girl_goldenretriever just happened to be filming when Lexi looked at a public fountain and clearly thought, yes, this pool will do. In the viral video, this adventurous Golden Retriever ignores the intended purpose of the stone structure. And tries to force a spa day, instead. It‚Äôs one of those moments that makes you nod if you‚Äôve ever lived with this breed ‚Äî water first, details later. It‚Äôs the scramble that gets you ‚Äî halfway clumsy, halfway determined, and very on brand.

Owner explains Golden Retriever‚Äôs logic behind taking dip in fountain thinking it‚Äôs a pool

Lexi starts by propping her front paws onto the edge of the fountain. She doesn‚Äôt hesitate before splashing her legs into the main bowl.On-screen text pops up saying, ‚ÄúGolden Retriever Logic: If it has water, it‚Äôs a pool,‚Äù which honestly explains everything that follows. Lexi isn‚Äôt one to let a little thing like ‚Äúpublic decorum‚Äù stand in the way of a good cool soak.

It does, however, get a bit clumsy once she tries to pull her back legs into the mix. Lexi is a big girl, and this fountain was definitely not designed for a full-grown dog. She slips once, wobbles, and somehow wedges herself between the bowl and a stone slab. It looks incredibly uncomfortable, but she manages to squeeze her fluffy body into the tiny space.

Soon though she realizes the ‚Äúpool‚Äù is a bit of a tight fit. She hops out gracefully and immediately gives a massive shake, spraying water everywhere. Fans loved the clip, with one viewer noting that their own dog, Blaze, does the exact same thing. Another joked that Lexi was absolutely convinced she could make it work.

The post has 3700 likes and counting. It only goes to show Lexi‚Äôs definition of pool didn‚Äôt go unnoticed. Watching her treat a tiny fountain like a five-star resort is a total mood. And we can‚Äôt wait to see where she finds her next swimming spot.

The post Video: Golden Retriever Goes for Swim in Fountain Thinking It‚Äôs a Pool appeared first on DogTime.

item.description:
In the discourse around weight gain and blood sugar management, insulin is usually vilified and given a bad reputation. But there is more to this picture, and it is usually insulin resistance, not insulin itself, that lies at the root of the problem.

ALSO READ: Does your eyelid twitch randomly? NHS doctor explains medical cause of weird but common symptoms that people experience

Dr Amir Khan, a general practitioner working in the UK-based National Health Service, revealed in an Instagram post on January 5, dispelling common fears around insulin and explaining how small changes can help improve insulin sensitivity.

To show insulin's role in a positive light, he called out all the fears around it, saying it has had a ‚Äòbad PR team and actually, insulin is a vital hormone which is responsible for moving sugar from blood to cells for energy. The actual problem arises, not from insulin's basic existence, but when it is too much, exceeding the normal levels, which is when cells stop reacting to it. This is called insulin resistance, and it is a major health concern as it is associated with weight gain, inflammation, type 2 diabetes, heart disease, and fatigue.

But the doctor assured that insulin sensitivity can improve, and it is very changeable:

1. Move your muscles

The first recommendation to reduce insulin sensitivity is to move your muscles. Dr Khan stated that muscles act like insulin sponges. Explaining this, he said, ‚ÄúWhen you move, particularly things like strength training, brisk walking, short bursts of higher effort, your muscles take up glucose without needing much insulin." But one doesn't need to spend hours in the gym because, as per the doctor, consistent activity matters more than intensity. What does this mean? If you regularly incorporate movement into your day, even if for a few minutes, such as brisk walk after meals, your health improves.

2. Give insulin a break

How often you eat can impact insulin levels and, in turn, insulin sensitivity too. Dr Khan asserted that insulin is actually meant to rise and fall, not stay elevated for extended periods, reiterating that you should avoid keeping insulin switched on all day.
How do you prevent? He said, ‚ÄúThings that can help with that are leaving gaps between meals, reducing constant snacking, and eating meals that include protein, fibre, and healthy fats.‚Äù When you follow these practices regularly, the cells become more responsive to insulin levels.

3. Sleep more, stress less

Sleep and stress are equally important when it comes to insulin regulation. A chain reaction occurs: when you sleep less, cortisol rises, and this stress hormone is also responsible for increasing blood sugar. The doctor noted that even a few nights of poor sleep can affect insulin. The key point to remember, according to Dr Khan, is that insulin is not the main culprit, but when it is overworked, the body's system breaks down, leading to fatigue, weight gain, and long-term metabolic issues.

Note to readers: This report is based on user-generated content from social media. HT.com has not independently verified the claims and does not endorse them. This article is for informational purposes only and not a substitute for professional medical advice.

item.title: DelrayÂåªÁîüÂú®‰∏âÊ¨°ÊøíÊ≠ª‰ΩìÈ™å‰∏≠Âπ∏Â≠ò‰∏ãÊù•ÔºåÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂÖ≥‰∫éÂåªÁñó‰øùÂÅ•ÁöÑ‰ø°ÊÅØË¶ÅÂàÜ‰∫´- Sun Sentinel
item.description:
By all measures, Dr. Tim Williams should not be alive.

Williams, 69, has survived a fall while home alone, a brain bleed, a coma for nine days, and in-bed surgery to drain fluid buildup in his brain ‚Äî and a major recovery effort.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs at least three times I could have easily died,‚Äù Williams said.

Williams had previously spent his days overseeing the delivery of radiation therapy to patients as the director of The South Florida Proton Therapy Institute at Delray Medical Center. But on the first Saturday in March, he was at his Lake Worth Beach home, alone.

Sara, his wife of only a few months, was hundreds of miles away in Washington, D.C., and felt something was wrong when her husband didn‚Äôt respond to her morning calls and texts. She asked a neighbor to check on him. The neighbor found Williams semi-conscious on the floor with a bruise on his head and called for an ambulance.

Williams said when the emergency crew arrived, his brain was in¬† an ‚Äúactive bleed.‚Äù

It‚Äôs unclear if the otherwise healthy doctor fell and hit his head, causing the brain bleed, or if an aneurysm caused the bleed and fall. Regardless, his medical condition became precarious.

‚ÄúIt is as if your body is an hourglass, and every second that passes places you in more peril as your life force is leaking out through the bottom,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúIf appropriate care isn‚Äôt delivered within time, the sand runs out, and your next stop is the funeral home. No one on earth knows the exact amount of time you have left. One thing is clear, though, is that there isn‚Äôt much. It is measured in minutes, not hours.‚Äù

Inside the ambulance, his condition deteriorated quickly. Emergency crews typically take patients to the nearest hospital, but they suspected a stroke and took Williams to Delray Medical Center, a recognized Comprehensive Stroke Center.

‚ÄúIf there is one thing I am sure of, it is that if it weren‚Äôt for the quality and professionalism of the physicians and staff at Delray Medical Center, I would have died. I‚Äôm a very lucky guy. My journey has taken me from being perhaps 15 minutes from death to an almost complete recovery.‚Äù ‚Äî Dr. Tim Williams

Later, Williams wrote a thank-you letter to the hospital staff describing the events.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been on the staff at Delray Medical Center since 1989 and served four years as a member of the senior governing board. None of this was known to anyone involved on the morning of March 1, 2025, when the ambulance picked me up, near death, on the floor at the foot of my bed,‚Äù Williams wrote. ‚ÄúMy neurologist would later tell me that, at the time, I only had perhaps another 20 to 30 minutes to live.‚Äù

Hospital staff immediately took a scan that showed a severe brain bleed.

‚ÄúThey couldn‚Äôt tell if it was a full-blown stroke or aneurysm or any of that, but they did see blood,‚Äù Sara Williams said. ‚ÄúSo it was just kind of a waiting game to see if the blood would drain the normal way, but it didn‚Äôt. He just got worse and worse and worse.‚Äù

For three days, Williams drifted in and out of consciousness, only to suffer a huge setback. He became completely confused, an indication of fluid buildup in his brain. The staff did another MRI.

‚ÄúCompletely unconscious, blood pressure dropping, I was hauled immediately back to radiology for an emergency MRI scan of my brain,‚Äù Williams said. ‚ÄúThe images were bleak. Blood was everywhere.¬†‚Ä¶ This prompted a spinal tap, which showed blood around my spinal cord. And, as if that wasn‚Äôt enough, my brain was swollen.

‚ÄúI was dying, again,‚Äù he said.

Neurosurgeon Dr. Ron Young arrived to see his friend in trouble. ‚ÄúWhen I got there, he was barely responding at all,‚Äù Young said.

With no time to secure an operating room, Young called for a craniotomy tray and, at the bedside, drilled a hole in Williams‚Äô scalp. He stuck a small drainage tube into the middle of Williams‚Äô brain.

‚ÄúWithin a few minutes, he was more responsive and started talking,‚Äù Young said. ‚ÄúBleeds are relatively common. We see this fairly often. Not finding the cause is quite uncommon.‚Äù

Young said it‚Äôs a true miracle that Williams survived all he endured: ‚ÄúIf appropriate treatment isn‚Äôt delivered, outcomes are poor,‚Äù he said.

Soon after Young drained the fluid, Williams slipped into a coma, where he remained for nine days. During that time, he battled aspiration pneumonia, yet he doesn‚Äôt remember anything.

When he finally awoke, he had a long, hard recovery ahead.

‚ÄúHe was not mobile whatsoever,‚Äù Sara Williams said. ‚ÄúThe physical therapy staff came for the first time to stand him up and get him out of the bed, and that‚Äôs when we found out that he wasn‚Äôt able to walk.‚Äù

At rehab, Williams underwent physical therapy, occupational therapy, and speech therapy.

After 43 days at Delray Medical Center and then its rehabilitation facility, Williams finally went home ‚Äî still unable to fully walk or use his hands and struggling with short-term memory.

‚ÄúWhen we came home, it was actually the scariest part of the whole ordeal,‚Äù his wife said. ‚ÄúHe was tired a lot. He could not tolerate a lot of motion or activity around him.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt wasn‚Äôt summer camp, but I did everything I was told, worked hard, and did as much as possible to assist with my own recovery,‚Äù Williams said.

As a patient, rather than a doctor, Williams says he has seen health care from a different perspective: ‚ÄúIf there is one thing I am sure of, it is that if it weren‚Äôt for the quality and professionalism of the physicians and staff at Delray Medical Center, I would have died. I‚Äôm a very lucky guy. My journey has taken me from being perhaps 15 minutes from death to an almost complete recovery.‚Äù

Nine months after his ordeal started, Williams says he still tires easily and describes himself as 80% back to normal. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt think I‚Äôll ever get back to 100,‚Äù he said.

He doesn‚Äôt plan to return to work in the same capacity.

‚ÄúMy clinical days are pretty much done. It‚Äôs too stressful. There‚Äôs too medical decision-making,‚Äù he said. Instead, he plans to conduct research in radiation oncology.

Williams wants others to learn from his experience. He says the medical staff‚Äôs knowledge of strokes and brain bleeds in the neurology ICU made all the difference in his survival.¬† The message he wants to get out is that anyone with stroke symptoms needs to go to a stroke center.

‚ÄúI was in the right place at the right time,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúI was lucky.‚Äù

South Florida Sun Sentinel health reporter Cindy Goodman can be reached at cgoodman@sunsentinel.com.
item.author: Sun Sentinel

item.title: ‰øÑÂÖãÊãâËç∑È©¨Â∑ûÂç´ÁîüÂ±ÄÊãíÁªùÂàÜ‰∫´ÂéøÁ∫ßÈ∫ªÁñπÊï∞ÊçÆ-‰øÑÂÖãÊãâËç∑È©¨Â∑ûËßÇÂØü
item.description:
Outbreaks of measles and whooping cough in Oklahoma have led to calls for greater transparency from the Oklahoma State Department of Health as the state stands alone in only sharing measles cases on a statewide basis.¬†

Infectious disease and public health experts said the timely sharing of cases with the public can help communities mitigate the spread of disease.

Dr. George Monks, a Tulsa dermatologist and former president of the Oklahoma State Medical Association, has been trying for months to get the state Health Department to share more data. He‚Äôs employed social media cajoling, open records requests and complaints to the attorney general‚Äôs public access counselor, to no avail.¬†

‚ÄúThis data is crucial for Oklahoma families to make informed decisions about their health, whether it be vaccine choice or avoiding high-risk areas,‚Äù Monks said. ‚ÄúWithholding that county-level measles data could delay the community response, especially since it is so contagious.‚Äù¬†

To date, Oklahoma has recorded 17 cases of measles in 2025. Nationally, the United States has had the highest number of measles cases in three decades. More than 800 of the 2,000 U.S. cases this year came in Texas back in the spring, although South Carolina is dealing with a current outbreak.¬†

Measles is a highly contagious, airborne virus with symptoms including rashes, high fevers, coughs, runny nose and red, watery eyes. The virus spreads through the air when an infected person coughs or sneezes. It can linger for up to two hours in a room after exposure.¬†¬†

Monks first requested measles case data by county in March, along with agency communications with the federal Centers for Disease Control and Prevention about a measles outbreak in Oklahoma. The state Health Department provided some email correspondence with CDC, but it cited a section of the federal Health Insurance Portability and Accountability Act, or HIPAA, in declining to release county measles data. Monks shared his requests and responses with Oklahoma Watch.¬†

In its Oct. 30 letter siding with the state Health Department, the attorney general‚Äôs office said the agency‚Äôs response was reasonable and noted its website has statistical information related to measles and potential public exposure.¬†

‚ÄúBased on the information available to me at this time, I conclude that OSDH has a good-faith legal basis to deny access to the records sought by Dr. Monks,‚Äù wrote Anthony Sykes, the attorney general‚Äôs public access counselor.¬†

Oklahoma is the only state not providing measles cases by county or on a regional level, according to researchers at Johns Hopkins University. They published a study in September in JAMA, the journal of the American Medical Association, detailing their efforts to develop the U.S. Measles Tracker.¬†

Kansas only withholds county-level measles data if the cases are fewer than five, the researchers noted. Tennessee, Utah and Iowa provide regional case data, but not by county.¬†

‚ÄúSingle measles cases often represent the leading edge of potential outbreaks, making their rapid identification crucial for public health response,‚Äù the researchers said in a supplemental paper describing their methodology. ‚ÄúGeographic specificity, even for small case counts, enables public health officials to implement targeted contact tracing and exposure notifications.¬†

‚ÄúMany state health departments routinely report individual measles cases in public communications, press releases, and exposure notifications, establishing precedent that individual case disclosure serves legitimate public health purposes.‚Äù¬†

Oklahoma used to disclose county-level measles cases as recently as 2019, during the last major measles outbreak. Media reports from that outbreak show measles in Okmulgee County.¬†

In an emailed response to questions from Oklahoma Watch, the state Health Department said its public data is sufficient to inform local communities of potential exposure to measles.¬†

It provides overall case counts, vaccination status, age range, median age of cases and any public exposure settings identified through investigation of a measles case.¬†

‚ÄúIdentified exposure locations are what pose a risk of spread to the public, and the county of residence may not always reflect the population or communities that may be at risk during a public health investigation,‚Äù the agency said.¬†

The state Health Department didn‚Äôt directly address questions on how other states are able to report county measles data. The agency said it continues to rely on its interpretation of federal HIPAA laws and Oklahoma‚Äôs public health code in not releasing county-level measles data.¬†

‚ÄúAccordingly, OSDH has the discretion to determine the manner in which statistical communicable disease data may be released to the public to the extent that such release is in compliance with de-identification and disclosure requirements of HIPAA,‚Äù the department said in the email.¬†

Echoes of COVID

The debate over how and when to share infection data echoes those in the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic. Oklahoma was slow to share community-level infection data. Even then, it provided county-level case information.¬†

In those first few months of the pandemic, Oklahoma Watch requested de-identified COVID-19 data from the state Health Department, including by city and ZIP code. Officials initially denied the request based on federal and state privacy laws, although those laws include exemptions to allow de-identified data. As the pandemic escalated, state health officials eventually provided localized data for COVID infections on an online data dashboard.¬†

The state Health Department said it used a risk-based approach to reporting COVID-19 cases to make recommendations around public gatherings and school closures.¬†

‚ÄúThe only way to implement such a system was to report ZIP code-level data,‚Äù the department said. ‚ÄúFor measles, using exact public setting location and time provides individuals the information necessary to communicate the risk to the public. Again, it‚Äôs all about risk and managing it in such a way as to balance the public‚Äôs need to know with our obligation to protect an individual‚Äôs health information.‚Äù¬†

The state Health Department sent out potential measles exposure alerts earlier this year. The alerts included the addresses of stores and restaurants an infected person had visited.¬†

Oklahoma public health officials withholding of county-level measles data contrasts with the state‚Äôs tracking for West Nile virus, a mosquito-borne disease. The state Health Department‚Äôs infectious disease website includes the number of cases and county of incidence for that virus.¬†

‚ÄúI don‚Äôt get it,‚Äù Monks said. ‚ÄúThey‚Äôre citing these privacy concerns (for measles), but there‚Äôs no patient data assigned to this. It‚Äôs all just aggregate data. I don‚Äôt get how they can come down on one side and then a different side based on the infectious disease.‚Äù¬†

The state Health Department said decisions about releasing county-level data are made based on a number of factors, including overall case count, population of the county and case investigation impact.¬†

‚ÄúFor some diseases, like West Nile, it is important that the public is aware of the geographic location of the case to communicate the risk of disease to the public,‚Äù the agency said. ‚ÄúThe majority of diseases publicly reported on our website are stratified by their respective region, rather than county-level, to help protect patient privacy, while still providing the public with a geographic distribution of disease burden.‚Äù¬†

Monks continues to request disease data from the Health Department. He‚Äôs asked for more information about pertussis, commonly called whooping cough, and tuberculosis.¬†

‚ÄúThis is a really important time to get this data out to the public,‚Äù Monks said. ‚ÄúIn Oklahoma, this is the worst whooping cough outbreak in 70 years and the worst measles outbreak we‚Äôve had in 35 years.‚Äù¬†

Monks said it‚Äôs a policy decision, not necessarily a public health decision, to withhold detailed data about respiratory disease outbreaks. Monks, who describes himself as a Reagan Republican, suspects some state leaders don‚Äôt want to raise the ire of the federal Health and Human Services Department under the leadership of Robert F. Kennedy Jr., a longtime vaccine skeptic.¬†

‚ÄúFrom the Republican standpoint, some have taken this position that this is a political football, and they really want to get away from pro-vaccinations and pro-science, especially in a primary,‚Äù Monks said.¬†

Paul Monies has been a reporter with Oklahoma Watch since 2017 and covers state agencies and public health. Contact him at (571) 319-3289 or pmonies@oklahomawatch.org. Follow him on Twitter @pmonies.¬†

Support our publication

Every day we strive to produce journalism that matters ‚Äî stories that strengthen accountability and transparency, provide value and resonate with readers like you.

This work is essential to a better-informed community and a healthy democracy. But it isn‚Äôt possible without your support.
item.author: Oklahoma Watch

item.title: ÊàëÂàöÂàöÁü•ÈÅìÁöÑÂ§±ÂéªÁà∂‰∫≤ÁöÑÊÇ≤‰º§-‰º§Âè£
item.description:
Photo-Illustration: The Cut; Photo: Courtesy of Subject

I first met my biological father on a blistering summer afternoon. He stood up from his porch swing, unfolding his tall lean frame like a stork. His corporality shocked me; I realized I had been searching for him for so long ‚Äî nearly three decades ‚Äî that a part of me believed I would never find him. Unable to summon a single word, I locked¬†eyes with him and tried to slow my racing thoughts, breathing in the dry Central Valley air. Finally, in a loud, clear voice he announced, ‚ÄúAnd you must be Heather.‚Äù

Hugging the man who had given me 23 chromosomes, whose eyes were the same icy-blue color as mine, whose ears, large and close to his head, resembled my sons‚Äô, felt like relief. I was surprised by the unexpected familiarity of his embrace. When he shared that ‚Äúever since Dr. Rock had said he‚Äôd been ‚Äòsuccessful,‚Äô he‚Äôd wondered about me,‚Äù I was gratified that just as I had imagined¬†him, so too had he imagined me.

When I was 36, a year after my father‚Äôs death ‚Äî the father who had raised me, the librarian who had given me my love of words, books, and my restless curiosity ‚Äî my mom and I were pushing my toddler twins in their Fisher-Price swings when she said she had something to tell me.

‚ÄúHoney, Dr. Rock mixed the sperm.‚Äù

‚ÄúMom, what are you talking about?‚Äù

‚ÄúOh, it was just a technique they used to help your father‚Äôs sperm.‚Äù

‚ÄúBut whose sperm did they use for the mixing?‚Äù

‚ÄúOnly the tallest and brightest medical students.‚Äù

‚ÄúSo, I‚Äôm the child of some random medical student?‚Äù

‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be silly. You‚Äôre your father‚Äôs daughter.‚Äù

I‚Äôd known my parents were married for seven years before I was born and that they had been patients of Dr. John Rock, the Harvard gynecologist and researcher who developed the birth-control pill. But this was the first I‚Äôd heard that my conception had been anything out of the ordinary and that I might not be biologically related to my father. I began bombarding my mom with questions that she couldn‚Äôt answer. Finally, irritated at my inquisition, she waved her hands in the air and admonished me to ‚Äúcurb my wild imagination.‚Äù

Having just endured my own infertility odyssey, I knew that what she was suggesting was a biological impossibility: I couldn‚Äôt be the result of a sperm cocktail. Her insistence on this fiction made me wonder, Was this it? Was this the secret I‚Äôd sensed being kept from me in our tiny family of three my entire life? I remembered how often my parents had remarked over my blue eyes ‚Äî ‚ÄúFrench blue,‚Äù my father called them, ‚Äúlike no one else‚Äôs in our family.‚Äù His eyes had been brown, my mom‚Äôs green. Sometimes I would hear them whispering my name when they thought I wasn‚Äôt around, or I would notice my father staring at me. When we looked at photos together, my mom was always quick to point out how similar my father‚Äôs and my profiles were. I caught myself running my finger up and down my nose, hunting for a bump like his.

My father died before home DNA testing had become as accessible as a trip to Duane Reade, when it was still expensive and difficult to solve questions of paternity. In the years following my mother‚Äôs confession, I tried to forge a fragile peace with the unsettling notion that I might never learn my biological father‚Äôs identity.

Then, when I was 62, over two decades after my father‚Äôs death and five years since my mother‚Äôs, I finally told my doctor the ‚Äúmixing‚Äù story. To my surprise, she took me seriously and handed me an Ancestry DNA test, one of those you can order online for $40 and get results in a month. That‚Äôs when I learned about my half-sister ‚Äî the simple fact of her existence proved definitively that I had been right. A friend later told me about DNAngels, an organization that helps unite family members, and eventually we connected. Tiffany is my almost-twin, just three days older than me.

We began emailing, then talking on the phone, then texting, trying to untangle the various strands of our shared DNA.¬† She had never questioned her own birth story ‚Äî she didn‚Äôt know if her parents had ever been patients of Dr. Rock ‚Äî but she was eager to learn more. Four months after our first conversation, she drove from Pennsylvania to spend a summer weekend at our family‚Äôs log cabin in New Hampshire. While the ceiling fans whirred and we sipped hot coffee at the dining room table, we spread out photographs of us as children, and of our kids, as well as various family trees we‚Äôd constructed. We must be related through our paternal side, we figured, but the rest was a mystery.

‚ÄúMaybe we could find some information about donors in Dr. Rock‚Äôs
papers at Harvard Medical School,‚Äù she said.

‚ÄúBut they‚Äôre sealed for the 80 years following their donation.‚Äù

‚ÄúStill, it‚Äôs worth a try.‚Äù

My sister‚Äôs optimism bolstered me. Before we said good-bye, we agreed to schedule a fall visit to the Countway Library at Harvard Medical School, a library my father built. We spent the next few months following the winding trail of Dr. Rock‚Äôs papers, but we came away from our first visit disappointed. Because we were born in 1959, an era when donor inseminations were unregulated and anonymous, we had only guessed at which papers, among the thousands, to request.

Now that we were invested in this search, neither of us could give up. Tiffany came back to Boston on a subzero January day, and we returned to the basement of the library together. When I had to leave for work, she kept digging. After she unearthed a list of men‚Äôs names, she texted me from the library, ‚Äústruck gold.‚Äù Surmising that these names might belong to members of the Harvard Medical School class of 1960, she cross-checked every one. Early that spring, I drove south to Lancaster so we could compare our results. When I arrived, she handed me a yearbook. The man she had identified as our biological father stared back at us.

Sitting at her kitchen island, together we scoured the internet for any crumbs we could find about him. We learned that he had lived in North Carolina, Hawaii, and finally California where he had practiced dermatology into his late 70s. He was on Facebook but hadn‚Äôt posted recently. Before we could chicken out, we messaged him saying only that we wanted to connect with him. But when he didn‚Äôt answer, we began to worry that we‚Äôd offended him. Tiffany suggested that, after I got home, we should enlist the DNAngels again. When they confirmed that he had to be our father, they produced his email, snail mail, and phone number and urged us to call him immediately ‚Äî he was almost 90. I called Tiffany.

‚ÄúDo you think we should call him?‚Äù

‚ÄúBut what if he doesn‚Äôt want to talk to us?‚Äù

‚ÄúWe could email him?‚Äù

‚ÄúI think we should write him a letter, that way he has more time to respond.‚Äù

We agreed that I would compose a letter sharing some of the basic outlines of our lives and our families, saying that we would like to explore our connection. Before I slipped the letter in the mailbox, I snapped a photo of it and texted it to Tiffany. Once it was in the mail, we began counting days. Although we hoped he would respond, we volleyed back and forth the many reasons why he might not: Maybe he didn‚Äôt want his family to know about us; maybe he was concerned with protecting his privacy; maybe he just didn‚Äôt want to have anything to do with children resulting from sperm he had donated in secrecy 64 years earlier.

His first email arrived in our inboxes three days later: ‚ÄúI have always wondered when this day would come. Happily, it is not from someone about to marry one of my children.‚Äù

Dick ‚Äî as he asked us to call him ‚Äî began emailing Tiffany and me several times a day, then several times a week. Just as we wanted to know about him, he had even more questions for us. We traded long and friendly emails about our education, our careers, our kids, and his memories of working for Dr. Rock. Unlike my parents, he was forthcoming in his descriptions of the fertility clinic where he had donated sperm. He described the end of his first marriage, and his happiness in his second, as well as his pride in his four children. Although our father had three sons and one daughter, none had chosen to become parents. My sister‚Äôs two children and my three would be the first biological grandchildren he‚Äôd known. A few weeks into our correspondence, he invited us to visit him in California that summer.

My son and his wife drove Tiffany and me from Oakland to Sacramento where Dick, his wife, and two of his children were waiting for us. After greeting us on the porch, they ushered us into his plant-filled living room. On our way down the hallway, he pointed out several photos of his daughter and his sister that reminded him of us. After a brief silence, the seven of us sat down in a circle and began comparing eyes, ears, and noses. His son kept saying how strange it was to have us all in the same room, strangers who looked so alike. I sat beside his daughter and we pressed our palms together, noting the similarities in the shapes of our fingers.

He was curious about how we had found him so we told him about our archival sleuthing. We asked him what he could remember about Dr. Rock. The fertility doctor had chosen him to be one of the fellows who operated the night switchboard. In return, he received a free room above the clinic. Whenever the doctor needed a sperm specimen for an insemination or for one of the research studies he was conducting, Dick obliged. For each donation, he was paid $25 ‚Äî enough for him to eat out for a week in Boston. More recollections returned to him; he laughed when he told us that the doctor had also kept a stash of Swedish magazines just for his donors.

He‚Äôd spent the majority of his life in California, but he‚Äôd grown up in New England, not far from where I was born, just a few miles from where I live now. He‚Äôd spent his summers working in a grocery store and sailing in a small beach town on Cape Cod, a place I had often vacationed. Although he‚Äôd chosen to attend medical school, he‚Äôd been an English major who had also enjoyed writing poetry. He loved that I was a writer and that Tiffany was a doctor ‚Äî ‚ÄúMy two halves,‚Äù he joked.

A little over two years after that visit, I opened an email from his eldest son: ‚ÄúDad passed away at home this morning, peacefully.‚Äù I was sitting in a friend‚Äôs knotty-pine-walled cabin on Mt. Desert Island in Maine. The mid-September night, just before the equinox, was filled with stars, and crickets chirped outside the door. Sinking into the soft gray couch, my small, scruffy black pup curled into me, I scrolled through my phone looking for his last text. Exactly two months earlier, I‚Äôd sent him a photo of my first grandson swaddled in a white blanket, taken at five hours old, his scrunched-up face red from the arduous journey to being born. Dick replied instantly,¬†‚ÄúHow excited you must all be!‚Äù

With my parents gone for decades, having a father again had offered the reassurance and comfort provided by having another generation in front of me. Eager to see him again, Tiffany and I were talking about visiting him later in the fall, perhaps around Thanksgiving. We had penciled in the dates, but we hadn‚Äôt bought our tickets yet. Even though Dick had been in good health for his age, he was starting to slow down. Now I was chastising myself for not getting on a plane. It‚Äôs not exactly a surprise when someone in their 90s dies, but still, we‚Äôd thought we had more time.

On that island in Maine, as the breeze blew through the window and my pup sighed, I wasn‚Äôt sure how to name what I was feeling. I remembered the way I had felt after my pregnancy losses ‚Äî I‚Äôd had three miscarriages and an ectopic pregnancy decades earlier ‚Äî after the idea of a baby had been ripped from me. I was mourning not only what was but what might have been, what I‚Äôd begun to let myself imagine. I felt grief for the man who had given me my cells and my life and grief for the man I had just been getting to know, for all that we might have learned about each other but now would not have the chance.

As I considered the loss of this surprise father, two years after I‚Äôd first seen Dick stand up from his porch swing, I returned to my phone, searching for more evidence of our connection. I realized that we‚Äôd been in touch every few weeks since that hot and humid day he‚Äôd first reached out his arms to me. In June, I‚Äôd sent him a poem I‚Äôd recently published,¬†‚ÄúSitting Out the Solstice Under a Japanese Maple Tree.‚Äù¬†He wrote back describing the covered porch swing he‚Äôd loved¬†‚Äúon a corner of the pasture‚Äù surrounding the farmhouse he‚Äôd built in the Russian River valley. Although he‚Äôd moved by the time we met, he talked fondly of this place, this land where he‚Äôd raised his family. He described the view from the swing:¬†‚ÄúOf a tree on the distant hill which was my solstice tree. The sun stopped there and made its turn. Not there to see it this year and probably never again.‚Äù

Reading his message again, I noticed he‚Äôd sent it almost exactly three months before he died. At the time, I‚Äôd interpreted it as a wistful sort of remembrance. But now I saw it as more prophetic¬†‚Äî¬†he‚Äôd known he was near the end. And, in this poignant last text, he matched his poems to mine, his words a salve for my grief.
item.author: The Cut

Unlike other dogs whose morning routines usually involve going for a walk, eating breakfast, and playing, this Golden Retriever‚Äôs routine is somewhat unusual. A video shared by @goldenchilidog on Instagram has been circulating around the internet. The video shows the winter routine of a dog named Chili, who can‚Äôt stop barking at rats. The clip amused viewers, and they flooded the comments section with love for the fur baby, calling him ‚Äútoo cute‚Äù and praising ‚ÄúChili‚Äôs energy!‚Äù

Golden Retriever even does it even when it‚Äôs snowy and everything is icy

This clip shared by @goldenchilidog on Instagram shows a dog enjoying time amid nature in the winter season, and the one usual activity he does every morning has left viewers amused. The video starts with the in-text title, ‚ÄúMorning routine of a lake dog winter edition,‚Äù and shows the Golden Retriever cuddling with his mom on the bed, enjoying his nap.

The next shot shows him wagging his tail as his mom asks for some more cuddles, and the video shows them bonding in the morning. The fur baby then relishes his breakfast as the lady prepares a cup of coffee for herself. It‚Äôs now time for Chili to go out and have fun. The dog goes to the lakeside that‚Äôs frozen and barks at it as the owner says, ‚ÄúEven in the winter, he is still looking for his muskrat,‚Äù further saying, ‚ÄúIt is here, it is not imaginary.‚Äù

The dog keeps barking, but no muskrat shows up, and he clearly looks disappointed. After barking at the lake to no avail, as he doesn‚Äôt see any muskrat, he doesn‚Äôt want to come back home. His mom asks him to come back and dry himself. After convincing him a lot, the dog finally gets back into the home and gets ready with help from his mom to go out.

However, as he still looks displeased, his owner tells him he will still find muskrat to bark at. After getting ready, they head out to a park, and while the lady is driving, she again jokingly asks, ‚ÄúMuskrat, where are you?‚Äù making the video even more hilarious.

Israeli scientists reveal how brain 'takes out the trash', and may spread Alzheimer‚Äôs

Technion researchers find protein-disposal system in brain cells may actually spread toxic proteins linked to Alzheimer‚Äôs; instead of destroying them, cells sometimes expel them to neighboring tissues, potentially accelerating disease progression in brain

item.description:
As Gow tells me, "If people don't believe change is possible, it's very unlikely that they're going to be open to an intervention‚Ä¶ Increasing the knowledge of what we can do to protect and promote brain health, whatever age we are, is fundamental". For instance simple actions could be trying a new exercise, finding a new hobby or joining a book group.

And for anyone ready to take these steps, combining changes in diet, exercise, cognitive training and cardiovascular health have been shown to have a significant improvement on brain health for older adults at risk of dementia.

This was shown in the landmark Finger (Finnish Geriatric Intervention) study, which involved 1,260 participants aged 60 to 77 who were randomly assigned into either an intervention group, where they underwent a two-year programme of lifestyle interventions, or a control group, who simply received regular health advice. The study found that compared to the control group, participants in the intervention group showed up to 25% greater improvement in overall cognitive function, as well as improvements in memory and problem solving. ¬†

And finally, when I ask Gow what his suggestion is for how to think about making lifestyle changes, he says it's about making "marginal changes today" and that there's no magic bullet. It's therefore clear that improvements across different areas of our life all add up and will provide us with lasting benefits, now and into the future.

* Melissa Hogenboom is BBC Global's Senior Health Correspondent.

item.description:
You know that feeling when you walk into a room and instantly wish you hadn‚Äôt interrupted? That‚Äôs exactly how this video shared by @sometimesbesties begins. Mom heads into the living room, probably expecting a normal scene, and instead finds her Golden Retriever, Harry, and his cat roommate, Sokka, locked in a cuddle situation that absolutely requires an explanation. Or maybe doesn‚Äôt. Either way, it stops her in her tracks. What‚Äôs unfolding on the couch looks equal parts affectionate and confusing. The kind of moment you only get when pets forget the rest of the world exists.

Mom dubs Golden Retriever and cat ‚Äòweirdos‚Äô after spotting unusual cuddle pose

Harry and Sokka are mid-snuggle when Mom approaches, and the timing could not be better. Sokka‚Äôs back legs are wrapped right around Harry‚Äôs snout, gripping his floppy cheek jowls in a way that makes it look like Harry is smiling on purpose. Harry, for his part, just freezes. He turns his head toward Mom and blinks slowly, like he‚Äôs silently asking for guidance ‚Äî or rescue.

Mom starts laughing immediately and asks what on earth they‚Äôre doing. Sokka responds by casually twitching his legs, which only exaggerates Harry‚Äôs forced grin. Then it gets even better. Sokka brings his front paws into the mix and starts kneading Harry‚Äôs face like it‚Äôs fresh dough. Harry, on the other hand, doesn‚Äôt move an inch. He just wags his tail a little, fully into to the frozen cuddle, no matter how awkward it‚Äôs getting.

When Mom finally says, ‚ÄúThanks, really, you two are weirdos,‚Äù Sokka looks away as if he‚Äôs not a part of this conversation at all. The cuddle breaks up soon after, but the cuteness lingers. The internet has seen everything.

The 42,000-plus likes tell us viewers are obsessed. Comments range from ‚ÄúPut a smile on doggo‚Äù to ‚ÄúNothing to see here, lady. Keep moving.‚Äù And honestly? They‚Äôre right. This is just a cat and his very patient dog, sharing a cuddle that somehow makes perfect sense to them ‚Äî and absolutely no sense to anyone else.

The post Golden Retriever & Cat Cuddling Together Labeled ‚ÄòWeirdos‚Äô in Funny Video appeared first on DogTime.
